Name: Painting Parlay
Description:
Painting Parlay is an educational game meant to teach the world's greatest artists, increase visual literacy for art, and identify elements of style. Players can vote if their opponents are correct, leading to a fun exploration of the arts.

Objective: Be the player or team with the most points after each player’s or team’s five cards have been placed with an artist. For a quick version of Painting Parlay use three cards instead of five.

Set-Up:
Layout the sixteen artists in a four by four grid on the table.
Shuffle the large square art cards and deal 5 cards to each player or team. Be sure not to look at the back of the art cards, as the artist is revealed on the backside of the card. 
Place the small hint cards painting side up, next to the artist grid, players can search the hint deck for a painting. 
Each player or team will take a voting card, and a point card with a clip to track their points.

Rules:
On your turn, you will choose a painting in your hand, examine its style and elements, and compare it to the sixteen artists on the table. 
You will then place your card with whom you think painted this painting, and give a brief reason on why you came to that conclusion.

Hints and Help:
If you are lost and need help you can search the hint deck for your painting, you will get fewer points if you choose correctly, however it will give you its date of creation, and information about the painting or artist. 
Artist Information: At any time on your turn, you can flip one artist card and read a brief summary of their life.
Exchanging Your Painting: Once per game you or your team can switch one of the paintings in your hand with one of the top three paintings of the art card deck. You will take your new painting and discard the painting in your hand.

Once you have chosen who you think painted your painting, the other players will vote, flipping their voting card to a check or an x, on whether they think you guessed correctly or incorrectly. Then flip the art card, and reveal the artist.

If you placed your painting next to the correct artist you will receive a point amount based on whether you used a hint or not. Adjust your scorecard using the sliding clip on the card. If you guessed incorrectly, you receive no points. 
Your turn ends and the next player seeks to match their painting with an artist.

Point Values:
Placed Painting Next to Correct Artist without a Hint: 5 points
Placed Painting Next to Correct Artist with a Hint: 3 points
If you voted correctly what the outcome would be: 2 points

Players continue to place their paintings with an artist until everyone has placed five of their paintings. In the quick version of Painting Parlay, it is only three paintings that are placed with an artist for the game to end.

Look at your scorecard and see who has the most points, that player or team is the winner! Congratulations on your mastery of the world’s most famous masterpieces.

Team Play:
In team mode, this game can accommodate up to eight teams of six players. Each player will receive one painting card and the voting card will be switched between players on a team each turn. Players on the same team can work together to figure out who painted a teammate’s painting and to vote, however it is up to the player whose turn it is to make the final choice. In team mode, players cannot exchange their painting cards for another. The game will end after six paintings have been placed next to an artist from each team.

Name: Business As Usual
Description:
Use your business savvy to outmanoeuvre your opponents and take control of the Island.
With a focus on player interaction, Business As Usual mixes the worlds of business and politics, in a faced paced negotiation and hand management game.


     Create revenue through business growth and self-benefiting deals
     Purchase influence to tilt the scales in your favour
     Vote for policy change to ensure the economy runs to your liking
     Outbid your opponents to put the rule bending lobbyists in your pocket


On this island, respect rules all!

Business as Usual is a 75 minute, 3-4 players game strategic Eurogame that incorporates aspects of trading, bidding, voting, and cutting deals to benefit your businesses. There are multiple routes to success, allowing everyone to be on the edge of their seat right to the end.

—description from the designer

Name: Myth: Forged in Fire Promo Card
Description:
Last of 4 promo Hero Cards for Myth released between 2014-2016. This card was released by Megacon at the GenCon 2016 Slaughterfield Event.

The card reads: "Stacked. Any Action may be played on top of this Card. That Action costs 0 AP."

Name: Jocul Autostrazilor
Description:
A Romanian strategy game for 2-6 players. You need to build as many highways as you can but be careful! Your opponents will sabotage you with unexpected incidents: a broken viaduct, an appeal to the public auction, blocking the works and see if you can repel the attack of opponents with negotiations, allocation of funds, any new builder or with some electoral promises.
It is recommended for 14+ years old players.

How to play:

     Cards with cities will be shuffled and equally distributed for all players. If any cards remain undistributed, you need to put them in a separate stack on the table.
     Cards with vignette will be stacked on the table.
     Cards with sabotage actions will be shuffled and given 10 to every player (if there are 6 players, any of them will be given 8 cards). The rest are placed on the table.


All players start from Bucharest and roll the dice. They need to move their pawn an equal number of points as corresponding on the dice (but he can't step twice on the same point in a turn). If the pawn is placed on a highway point, the player can ask for the related card, by initiating an act of sabotage against the player who owns that card.

What is sabotage:
Sabotage cards have a number of points (e.g.: 1 / 2 / 8 / 0.1 or -3 / -5 etc). A player who wants a card for a highway, needs to put down a sabotage card of negative value (e.g.: -3). The opponent must repel the attack with 1 or more cards with positive value until their sum is greater than the opponent's card (-1 equals +1 or overcome with +2). In case of equality, challenged player can keep his card. Otherwise, if the challenged player overcomes the attack, he can choose a card with cities from the player who initiated the attack. If the challenged player is defeated, the player who initiated the attack receives his requested card.

Vignette cards: 
Can be used only at border crossing points in order to obtain 3 sabotage cards OR to ask for any of highway city cards.
Every route has a specific number of points. The player with most points wins.

Name: 20 Dreams
Description:
20 Dreams is a storytelling card game where each player has a set of 20 emotion cards differentiated by colour. There is another set of white emotion cards in the centre along with picture prompt cards. 
On a player’s turn, they take one emotion card and three picture cards from the centre. They then have to tell a story that uses the picture cards to express the emotion on the white emotion card, which is to be hidden from the other players. The game is themed as if you are telling the group about a dream you had, so the picture cards contain many common dream themes like flying and teeth.
Once the player has told their story involving the 3 picture cards the other players have to guess what emotion was being expressed using their own emotion cards. Those who are incorrect have their corresponding emotion cards taken away (placed in the penalty box), and those that were correct give their cards to the storyteller, the person with the most cards at the end is the winner.

—description from the publisher

Name: Warhammer Age of Sigmar: Warcry – Skaven
Description:
Cunning and malevolent, the skaven seek to spread ruin and corruption wherever they go. This insidious race of vermin-men worships the foul god known as the Great Horned Rat, and their plots and schemes are truly diabolical in their complexity.

Kill-steal in Warcry yes-yes! Ahem. If you’re looking to start a Skaven warband for skirmish battles (or expand one!), this set is for you, giving you everything you need for a diverse warband of ratmen. It also contains a number of accessories to help you in your games. What’s more, you’ll save money compared to getting the models inside separately!

—description from the publisher

Name: Warhammer Age of Sigmar: Warcry – Ironjawz
Description:
The Ironjawz are the biggest and hardest orruks of all. Clad in thick pig-iron armour and swinging enormous, bone breaking weapons, they live for nothing more than the chance to wreak untold devastation across the realms.

If you’re looking to dominate the Eightpoints for Gorkamorka (or just for a good laugh), then this is the Warcry set for you! Designed to make kicking off or expanding a diverse warband of Ironjawz simple, it also contains a number of accessories to help you in your games. What’s more, you’ll save money compared to getting the models inside separately!

–description from the publisher

Name: Warhammer 40,000: Apocalypse – Datasheet Cards: T'au Empire
Description:
A set of Datasheets specifically designed for using your T’au Empire Citadel miniatures in games of Warhammer 40,000: Apocalypse. Each datacard provides the full rules and profiles for a single unit from the T’au Empire faction. Also included is a Faction card that details the faction rules that apply to T’au Empire Detachments. The reverse side of each card features the faction’s icon.

The set includes datacards for the following units:


     Commander Shadowsun
     Commander Farsight
     Commander
     Aun’Va Aun’Shi
     Ethereal
     Cadre Fireblade
     Darkstrider
     Longstrike
     Breacher Team
     Strike Team
     Kroot Carnivores
     Kroot Shaper
     Krootox Riders
     XV25 Stealth Battlesuits
     XV8 Crisis Battlesuits
     XV8 Crisis Bodyguards
     Firesight Marksman
     XV95 Ghostkeel Battlesuit
     XV104 Riptide Battlesuit
     Pathfinder Team
     TX4 Piranhas
     Tactical Drones
     Vespid Stingwings
     Kroot Hounds
     XV88 Broadside Battlesuits
     TX7 Hammerhead Gunship
     TX78 Sky Ray Gunship
     MV71 Sniper Drones
     TY7 Devilfish
     AX3 Razorshark Strike Fighter
     AX39 Sun Shark Bomber
     Tidewall Shieldline
     Tidewall Droneport
     Tidewall Gunrig
     KV128 Stormsurge


—description from the publisher

Name: Ugly Gryphon Inn: Local Dragons
Description:
You’ve handled plenty of rowdy customers in your time, from monks and mages to giants and goblins, but there’s one thing you’ve never faced: the mighty Dragon. Now your humble inn has drawn the attention of an ancient wyrm. Pay close attention to who leaves and who stays: if your departing Patrons irritate the lurking Dragon, all your hard work is sure to go up in flames!

Each game using the Local Dragons expansion adds 1 of 3 possible Dragons to your Inn. As Patrons leave, check their symbols to see whether they provoke the Dragon. If the Dragon is sufficiently provoked -- two matching symbols accumulated -- you’ll lose the game.

Name: Les Gens Qui
Description:
Les Gens Qui is THE party game to judge all the people who annoy us every day. It's a simple, fast and interactive card game.

The aim of the game? Try to guess what your friends think of these people.

Each player chooses a set of hand cards which will allow them to choose from 4 different sanctions: Heart On You, Just a Finger , One Year of Gulag or Death Sentence.

One the players is the judge. He takes 3 situation cards, reads them at loud and puts them face up in the middle of the board.

For example : 

     People who sniff instead of blowing their nose, 
     People who say "I'm not a racist, but...", 
     People who are ALWAYS late.


The judge gives his opinion by placing cards face down on the board. The other players do the same and vote, face down, trying to guess what the Judge has voted. The player who have the most answers in common with the Judge score 1 point for each correct answer!

—description from the publisher

Name: Les Gens Qui Trash
Description:
This game is an expansion pack for the “Les Gens Qui” board game. You will be able to judge even more trashy situations and try to guess what your friends think.

In Les Gens Qui - Trash expansion, you can find :


     330 new people cards to judge.
     1 new exclusive hand set to mix with the basic version hand sets for playing up to 9 players. 
     1 alternative game rule to discover a new game mode!


—description from the publisher

Name: Thesë Go to Eleven
Description:
A game of pushing your limits, and then some.


Inspired on the cult film This Is Spinal Tap.

Front is pure black. Tribute to fictional Spinal Tap's Black Album, who, in the classic 1984 movie This Is Spinal Tap, were forced to put out their album "Smell the Glove" with an all-black cover after their label refused to release the original, sexually offensive artwork.


Released in the November 2016 Board Game of the Month Club $5+ package.


GOAL
Be the first player to make the numbers 1 through 11 in order using die rolls and card play.

SETUP
Sort the cards by suit, then give each player A-2-3-4-5-6-7 cards of a suit. This is their Hand. The other cards aren't used.

GAMEPLAY
On your turn, choose to roll one or two dice. You will then use the sum of one or more cards to make one addition or subtraction by combining the sum of the card(s) from your hand with the die roll.

If the exact target number is rolled
You may choose to either:

     Stop rolling and draw one card from the center pool.
     Discard cards to the table face up to combine with your die roll to equal the desired number.


If the target number is not rolled
You must either:

     discard cards to the table face up to make your die roll equal the desired number.
     Choose to end your turn.


After a number is made (via the combination of dice and cards) you will choose to either:

     Continue to the next consecutive number.
     Pass your turn, and draw two cards from the center pool.


If a number cannot be made, you bust. Your turn ends and you draw no cards.

On every subsequent turn, you will begin by choosing 1 card from the common pool and achieve the same target number you failed at your last turn.

END OF GAME
When a player reaches 11, the game will end once all players have taken their turn. The first player to get a value of 11 is the winner, and if tied, the player with the largest sum of values in their hand wins the game.

Name: You're Tearing Me Apart
Description:
A legacy game where you throw cards, not footballs.

Inspired on the cult film The Room.


Released in the September 2016 Board Game of the Month Club $5+ package.


INITIAL SETUP
Separate the deck into red/black cards & remove the jokers; give one set to each player. Each player shuffles their deck and draws 5 cards.

GOAL
Earn the most points. Points accrue over games with the same deck.

TURN
You must choose one action:

     Draw: Draw from 1-5 cards from your deck, then discard that many cards. Discarded cards will not be available to you again this game.
     Play: Play one card from your hand to your tableau, then draw one card from your deck.
     Tear: Tear apart one card from a set in your tableau and throw half of it at your opponent's tableau.
     Replace: Replace a card matching the number of one of your previously destroyed cards with half of your destroyed card from your reserve, then throw that half at your opponent's tableau. Shuffle the whole card back into your deck, then draw one card.
     Score: Tear apart one card from a set, discard the rest of that set from your tableau, then add that set's value to your score (points according to a table). Add both halves to your reserve (instead of throwing that torn card).


TEARING APART & THROWING
You may tear apart any card in a set from your tableau to throw half at your opponent's tableau. If it touches any of your opponent's cards, you may choose one and any in its set to discard from the game. You earn half the points that your opponent would have earned from scoring that set. You determine which cards are in that set.

Once you have thrown half of a card, you cannot throw it again during that game.

SETS
A set is a grouping of paired and sequential cards played  to the tableau. It must meet all of the following three conditions:
1) To start a set, there must be a matching pair of numbers.
2) A set can be extended +1/-1 from any pair in the set. Aces wrap.
3) Sets must be touching each other in the tableau.

END OF GAME
When a player needs to draw but cannot, their opponent gets one final turn and the game ends.

SETUP FOR SUBSEQUENT GAMES
All torn cards are placed in your reserve at the start of the game.The starting player is the player with the current lower score.

END OF ALL GAMES
When the game ends without either player scoring any points, the game is all torn apart. The player with the highest total score wins.

Name: Time Machine Rocket
Description:
Time Machine Rocket is a fast, simple and fun card game. It has a great balance between strategy and luck, in addition to the possibility of interfering in the opponents' game.

The theme is inspired by time travel narratives that promote the unexpected encounter of figures from different eras. In short, the idea is to travel in time in search of forming the best team of historical personalities, bringing together figures such as Leonardo da Vinci and Bruce Lee.

In each turn, the player opens a card from the historic decks. She then decides whether to bring that character to her team, or to open a new card. If she opens a Rocket, she advances to the next deck. If she opens a character of the same type that she opened before, she now have to put that character on her team.

The game ends when a player forms a team of 5 characters, of 5 different types (Humanitarian, Military, Creative, Scientist and Explorer). The player sums up the numbers of each character, and the one with most points wins.

—description from the designer

Name: Warhammer 40,000: Crusade Mission Pack – Beyond the Veil
Description:
This mission pack is a narrative play expansion for the Warhammer 40,000 Crusade campaign system.

Within, you’ll find the rules required to play games of Warhammer 40,000 set in the mysterious region of space known as the Pariah Nexus. This mission pack has been specifically designed for use in narrative play Crusade games, where your armies will find themselves beset by the unsettling effects that earned the Pariah Nexus its ominous name. But whilst there is great danger to be found here, for those who are successful, the rewards are well worth the risk.

Inside this 112-page mission pack you will find:

- Six new missions each for Combat Patrol, Incursion, Strike Force and Onslaught sized games
- A selection of new Battle Traits and Crusade Relics
- A swathe of gaming material, including a new Theatre of War and a glossary

The pack itself is presented in a full Canadian wiro ring-bound book for easy use and reference on the tabletop during games, and comes with an elastic closure.

Name: Democracy: The Cards Game
Description:
In Democracy: The Cards Game, become the president of the  Banana Island Republic, the country where defending the indefensible will lead you to be the president of a nation.

What does washing dishes with a loaf of bread have to do with promoting the country's industry? Get your rhetoric and creativity to make your speech the most voted to achieve your goal, become a president.

How to play:

In Democracy: The Cards Game the players have to argue in a 60 second speech using the cards they have chosen, 2 cards from the matter deck and 1 card from the industry sector deck. After the argument, the players vote for the best speech. The speech of the player with the most votes wins the round. At the end of 5 rounds the player with the most votes wins.

2 Players:

The player who draws the victory symbol (^) when rolling the Supreme Court die begins.

Two subject cards and one sector card are handed out to be able to elaborate your speech. You have one minute to present your speech.

The first player makes his speech and both vote for the best, in case of a draw, the dice is rolled to decide who wins the round.

In case of a tie with the dice, the round ends and 2 cards per player are drawn again to start a new round.
If there is a winner, the winning player scores a point for each round won. At the end of 5 rounds the player with the most points wins

—description from the designer

Name: Math Rush: Multiplication & Exponents
Description:
Think fast in Math Rush, a totally thrilling cooperative math game that will make your heart race and your head rev. For three rounds, up to five players must balance strategy and speed, properly sequencing products and exponentials before the timer runs out. Crunch the numbers in a hurry and rack up more points; make an error and miss your goal. Whether you beat your high score or not, it's more fun that you calculated.

Math Rush is a timed, co-operative card game for 1-5 players who race to complete sets of matching cards in the right order.

In Math Rush: Multiplication & Exponents, the cards show products and exponentials that must be played in ascending or descending order, meeting the requirements of the goal cards (such as "Perfect Squares Only").

—description from the designer

Name: Math Rush: Fractions, Decimals, & Percents
Description:
Think fast in Math Rush, a totally thrilling cooperative math game that will make your heart race and your head rev. For three rounds, up to five players must balance strategy and speed, properly sequencing fractions, decimals, and percents before the timer runs out. Crunch the numbers in a hurry and rack up more points; make an error and miss your goal. Whether you beat your high score or not, it's more fun that you calculated.

Math Rush is a timed, co-operative card game for 1-5 players who race to complete sets of matching cards in the right order.

In Math Rush: Fractions, Decimals, & Percents, the cards show fractions, decimals, and percents that must be played in ascending or descending order, meeting the requirements of the goal cards (such as "Decimals Only").

—description from the designer

Name: Crystal Palace: The Newspaper Cards
Description:
With this mini-expansion, the newspaper track on your player boards is replaced by newspaper cards, which with their diverse effects will provide even more variety in your games of Crystal Palace.

For now, this extension is only available as "Print and Play".

Name: Meta Olympia: The Board Game
Description:
In Meta Olympia, you play a Martian colony 'football' club in the not-too-distant future, playing rules that resemble soccer on Earth. The objective of the game is to be the most bad-ass team on the planet by achieving the most combined point.  Player's teams are made up of athlete cards, each offensive, defensive or special abilities.

There are two different stages played over 4 rounds. In the Pre-Season phases, players take turns moving their miniatures forward along modular tiles.  Each tile either helps players improve their team (via recruiting and trading athlete cards) or collecting resources that improve players tactical options.

In the tournament round, players get to to go head-to-head against each other in player vs player matches. Matches are played in 3 rounds where each player uses one athlete card and a die role per round.  Players can also play tactics cards, resources earned from the pre-season phase, to buff or nerf.

Each round determines goals, saves, and potential injuries; with the final match result based on the final score of all 3 rounds.
As players move into the following stages, they have the resources to continually strengthen their team by adding higher-value players.

In tournament in stage 4 is the final championship.  For 2 players, it is a best of 5 matches.  For 3 or more players, it is a round robin. Players go all out to either defend their lead or challenge the leaders.

The final winner is determined by tallying up all the points collected, either through wins, game currency, or special resource cards.

-description from publisher

Name: Xenohunters
Description:
It’s the 36th century, and the world's citizens live in station colonies throughout the galactic rim. However, colonies living on the outer galactic rim are going dark and have become uncontactable.

The galactic council has expended their military forces to no avail - they need to call on the best.

You, the Xenohunters, have been summoned as the elite mercenary crew who live on the edge of the law to investigate the stations. You know very well: this is another outbreak of flesh-eating Xenos, creatures that harvest living flesh to birth monsters.

The only way to stop this advancing tide of evil is with the liberal application of fire. The best way to do so: detonate the fusion reactors at the heart of every station. As elite mercenaries of the galaxy, your mission is clear: board the stations, destroy the reactors, and kill the aliens.

Good luck.

Warp ends in 3, 2, 1…

Xenohunters is a thematically engrossing board game of adventure and horror. One player becomes the terrifying flesh-eating Xeno, and all other players take control of the crew tasked with working together to hunt them down: Warlord, Ironclad, Caduceus, and Armature.

Both teams will hunt each other throughout the station, choosing when to reveal themselves and stay hidden. A hidden location grid behind your player screen conceals your movements until the time is right to strike.

Xenohunters collect powerful sci-fi equipment to hunt the Alien. However, rummaging around for equipment and supplies can be dangerous, as any mistake can lead to you appearing for all to see...

Meanwhile, as the Alien crawl through ducts, lay eggs, command your minions to search and distract and sense the humans to lay the perfect traps. And if you kill a Xenohunter? They become their own worst enemy... hatching from one of your eggs as a horrific Hybrid Spawn.

Comes with four Core Mission boards, 40 unique sci-fi gadgets, guns, explosions, and terrifying Hybrid Spawn.

Name: Alhambra: Big Box (Second Edition)
Description: The Alhambra: Big Box (Second Edition) features all new artwork and includes all 6 expansions and the 2 Queenies amounting to 26 modules.
Families: Versions & Editions: Big Box Versions of Individual Games

Name: Evolve
Description:
Evolve is an intriguing new family board game for those who want something a little more interesting than traditional board games. It has some educational content too. Its for ages 9+ to adults and can be played by 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6 players in around 45 minutes. Great interaction between players as they try to gain the best habitat (Era cards) for their playing pieces and be first to create a path of six era cards (the habitat of creatures from bygone eras). Win by reaching the end card first with your playing piece. Era cards can gained in several ways including by an unusual auction (bid for habitat). All the while natural events (Thunderbolts) can spring up at random and hinder or sometimes help a player in his quest to reach the end of his/her path.

—description from the publisher

Name: Snowball Hostilities
Description:
In Snowball Hostilities players lead a team of kids against opponents in a series of wintry battles that take place in their backyard. Players can have their kids create, maintain, and transport a supply of snowballs and snow bricks as well as build snow walls for defense and snowmen that come to life and wreak havoc. Santa randomly appears in the game to drop presents that players can utilize such as snowmobiles, catapults, sleds, and a remote control airplane. To win players must sweep the other teams from the map or force them into resignation.

SEQUENCE OF PLAY
Each turn each kid, represented by a pawn, receives a number of action points. These can be used to move across the map, attack other players' kids, attempt to recruit new kids, or conduct other actions such as making, gathering, or transporting items. After players make their moves NPCs such as Santa, the elf, snowmen, and the dog will move randomly by roll of dice if they are on the map.

—description from the designer

Name: The Handbook for the Recently Deceased
Description:
A game of hiding, seeking and spooking.

Inspired on the cult film Beetlejuice.


Released in the December 2016 Board Game of the Month Club $5+ package.


A lovely couple has died, and in a panic to save their home from the living family that's moved in and ruined everything, accidentally unleashed a dangerous ghost promising to rid the house of the living.

SETUP
Choose one player to be the Bio-Exorcist. You are a ghost, and you are trying to scare the living residents of this haunted house out, by moving items spookily around their house.

The other players leave the room to split up 2+ roles: 1 Occultist, 1 Goth, and 0-3 Folks.

While they're gone, the Bio-Exorcist moves as many objects as the number of living players, and hides a spook (represented by a card or a coin) under each one:

     One spook is the postcard, The Handbook for the Recently Deceased.
     One spook (the joker or the largest coin) is Scared to Death.
     The rest of the spooks are the love of the ghost couple.


SPOOKING OBJECTS
An object you spook must be noticeable moved from where it started. To mess with their heads, the Bio-Exorcist may also move 3 more objects without hiding any spooks under them.

It's important that the Bio-Exorcist remembers where they put each card/coin. Record this info, if needed.

Finally, the Bio-Exorcist calls back the living and the game can begin.

PLAYING THE GAME
Each living player may ask one question of the Bio-Exorcist and may peek under one object. They may do this in any order, at any time; there are no turns.

The Bio-Exorcist must answer questions truthfully, but may interpret ambiguous wording as they please. They cannot speak, they answer only with knocks: once for "yes", don't knock for "no", in numbers knocking that many times.

When a living player peeks and finds a spook, they reveal it and earn another question and another peek.

WINNING AND LOSING
Anyone who reveals Scared to Death loses the game immediately.

If the Goth reveals the Handbook for the Recently Deceased, they get to fulfill their dream of becoming a ghost. The Goth and the Bio-Exorcist win.

If the Occultist reveals the Handbook for the Recently Deceased, they exorcise the Bio-Exorcist and the ghost couple. The Occultist and the Folks win.

If all of the love spooks are revealed, the ghost couple  and the living become friends, and get rid of the Bio-Exorcist. All of the living players win.

If no one has any peeks left and there are love spooks unfound, the living have been driven from the house. The Bio-Exorcist wins.

Name: Box Quiz: Julehygge
Description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Julehygge - Christmasspirit'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about the Danish Julehygge (Spirit of Christmas). It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

Name: Box Quiz: Dansk Byer
Description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Denmark's Cities'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about the cities of Denmark. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

Name: Box Quiz: Danske Øer
Description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Denmark's Islands'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about islands of Denmark. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

Name: Box Quiz: Verdens Historie
Description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'History of the World'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about the history of the world. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

Name: Box Quiz: Højskole
Description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Højskole'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about højskoler. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

Name: Trick or Repeat
Description:
A time-travelling trick taking card game.

Inspired on the cult film Donnie Darko.


Released in the October 2016 Board Game of the Month Club $5+ package.


SETUP
Deal 5 cards to each player face down. Form the Rabbit by dealing 5 cards face up in the center of the table, stacked bottom to top with all cards visible. The face up cards in the Rabbit set the trump suit in the five tricks to be played, in order from top to bottom.

RULES

1. Form timelines. Choose a card from your hand, place it face down in front of you. Then pass the remaining cards to the left, and repeat, placing later cards closer to the Rabbit to form a line extending from yourself, until all cards have been placed, in the order labeled Form Timeline. Do not look at the last card passed to you.

2. Predict the future. At the count of three, bid simultaneously on the number of tricks the player to your left will win.

3. Resolve tricks. In the order labeled Resolve Tricks, everyone reveals the next card in their timelines, and evaluate the trick. In the first trick, the player to the left of the dealer leads, and thereafter the player who won the previous trick leads. A trick is won by the highest card matching the lead player's suit, unless cards matching the suit of the current Rabbit card have been played, in which case the highest card in the Rabbit suit wins.

4. Score points. After all 5 tricks have been played, score points: 1 point for each won trick, and an additional 2 points for having correctly bid the number of tricks won by the player to your left.

TIME TRAVEL
After scoring once, the game "goes back in time". Pick up the last card in your timeline, labeled Time Travel. Then, moving towards the Rabbit, pick up 1 card at a time and place it on top of the others in your hand. Keep the cards face up when collecting and passing. Finally, starting with yourself, take the top card and pass the remaining cards to your right. Repeat until each player has 5 cards, the same cards they had at the beginning of the game.

WINNING
Add up scores from the two rounds to determine a winner.

Name: Europaeisches Reisespiel
Description:
"European travel game" published by Ernst Kuhn, Switzerland, 1892.
Typical roll and move game. First player, who completes the route wins the game.

—user summary

Name: Letterbound
Description:
A word game that can be played alone or with friends.

Players work together for a high score by forming tough words, but they cannot communicate during their turns. On each player's turn they will say a word outloud that includes at least 2 different letters that are currently shown on the board (and not covered).

Then they'll choose one of the letters in that word and place a penny on it, heads side up. If the word includes 3 different letters fromm the board, then the penny is placed tails side up.

The game ends immediately when one letter remains or a player cannot say a word that uses two letters. The last word cannot include a red letter.

SCORE: The blue outside spaces are worth one point and the purple inside spaces are worth two points. Any spaces with tails are worth one extra point.

Name: Vindication: Chronicles
Description:
The road to restoring your lost honor goes deeper with Chronicles, the second expansion to Vindication. Chronicles adds more narrative, immersion, and story to the existing Vindication experience, both for the island itself and for your own personal journey.

Narrative-choice chronicle cards add a layer of decision and intrigue that bring your story to life. Each time you gain a card in the game (companion, relic, trait, monster, pet, etc) another player will draw and read a chronicle card, which presents you with a narrative prompt and a decision, ultimately telling the story of how you obtained that card. As you grow your tableau, so too do you chronicle your own journey.

These decisions are further recorded on new, large, full color paper player sheets. Make enough decisions embodying a certain attribute and you become legendary for that attribute, gaining you a powerful new ability and a big gorgeous tarot card to place next to your wretch tile to help you feel extra good about your progress.

All the while, you must confront various global events that rage across the land. At times no one may visit an inn until all the bandits have been run off. Strange mists may make traveling the edge of the map extra perilous. Dozens of unique events change the game state in some dynamic way — until someone deals with it and claims a huge reward.

—description from the publisher

Name: Mitos y Leyendas: Guerrero Jaguar
Description:
"The Jaguar moves slowly, but its claws do not know mercy. Whoever moves through the jungle is the true master of life, the holder of the keys of death; the creator of a new tomorrow."

Guerrero Jaguar introduces the exciting stories of Mesoamerican mythology to the world of Myths and Legends. Discover exciting new strategies with this 236-card edition fully compatible with all previous Second Era editions.

This deck contains 50 tactical cards (5 Royals, 15 Courtesans, 15 Vassals and 15 Golds), mixed randomly, to enhance the highest Mythological strategies. Includes instructions for updated Rules. Recommended product for high level players.

—description from the back of the box (translated)

"El Jaguar se mueve despacio, pero sus garras no conocen la piedad. Quien se mueve entre la selva, es el verdadero amo de la vida, el poseedor de las llaves de la muerte; el creador de un nuevo mañana".

Guerrero Jaguar introduce al mundo de Mitos y Leyendas las emocionantes historias de la mitología Mesoamericana. Descubre nuevas y emocionantes estrategias con esta edición de 236 cartas totalmente compatibles con todas las ediciones anteriores de Segunda Era.

Este mazo contiene 50 cartas tácticas (5 Reales, 15 Cortesanas, 15 Vasallos y 15 Oros), mezcladas aleatoriamente, para potenciar las más altas estrategias Mitológicas. Incluye instructivo de Reglas actualizadas. Producto recomendado para jugadores de Alto Nivel.

—description from the back of the box

Name: Mitos y Leyendas: Guerrero Jaguar – Punta de Lanza
Description:
"The attack is the most effective defense, this is how we will attack constantly, until we break the tips of our spears, there will be no glory if there is no victory."

Guerrero Jaguar introduces the exciting stories of Mesoamerican mythology to the world of Myths and Legends. Discover exciting new strategies with this 236-card edition fully compatible with all previous Second Era editions.

This pre-built deck contains 50 tactical cards (4 Royals, 15 Courtiers, 16 Vassals, and 15 Golds) that power your Myths and Legends strategy. A rule book is included. The actual cards included in this deck do not appear in the improvement packs. Deck specially designed for Myths and Legends players who wish to perfect and learn new strategies.

—description from the back of the box (translated)

"El ataque es la defensa más efectiva, es así como atacaremos constantemente, hasta romper las puntas de nuestras lanzas, no habrá gloria si no hay victoria".

Guerrero Jaguar introduce al mundo de Mitos y Leyendas las emocionantes historias de la mitología Mesoamericana. Descubre nuevas y emocionantes estrategias con esta edición de 236 cartas totalmente compatibles con todas las ediciones anteriores de Segunda Era.

Este mazo preconstruido contiene 50 cartas tácticas (4 Reales, 15 Cortesanos, 16 Vasallos y 15 Oros) que potencian tu estrategia de Mitos y Leyendas. Se incluye un libro de reglas. Las cartas reales incluidas en este mazo no aparecen en los sobres de superación. Mazo especialmente diseñado para jugadores de Mitos y Leyendas que deseen perfeccionar y conocer nuevas estrategias.

—description from the back of the box

Name: Monopoly: Macau Edition
Description:
The properties are from streets and landmarks of Macau and are from Go onwards:

Calcada da Barra - Community Chest - Avenida de Amizade - Income Tax (Pay 10% or $2,000) - Ferry Terminal - Estrada de Cacilha -  Chance - Rua do Almirante Costa Cabral - Rorte de Mong Ha - Jail - Avenida Dr. Sun Yat Sen - Macau Electric - Estrada Do Altinho De Ha Ho - Estrada da Penha - Macau Bridge - Estrada Lou Lim Ieok - Avenida de Kwong Tung - Estrada Nordeste da Taipa - Free Parking - Estrada de Seac Pai Van - Chance - Avenida da Praia Grande - Estrada de Cheoc Van - Taipa-Coloane Causeway - Estrada de Hac Sa - Taipa Pequena - Water Works - Taipa Grande - Go To Jail - Avenida Infante D. Henrique - Vila Coloane - Community Chest - Guia Hill - Macau Airport - Chance - Ruins of St. Paul's - Salary Tax and Macau Casino.

Name: Jumping to Conclusions
Description:
A game about questions, answers and wild guesses.

Inspired on the cult film Office Space.


Postcard released in the June 2016 Board Game of the Month Club $10+ package.


SETUP
Remove the Jokers and split the deck into 4 suits.

Each player separates their J-Q-K and then makes a hand consisting of Ace through 10.

GAMEPLAY
The starting player makes a personal statement that involves a two-digit number. The number can include zero to make it single digits.

Each player must then make a claim using two face down cards from their hand to represent the digits.

After each player chooses their cards, all player will reveal their claims.

After the claims are revealed, players will use their J-Q-K to bet on the factual nature of any or all other player's claims:

     Jack: must be Joking. None of the digits are correct.
     Queen: not Quite right. One of the digits is correct and one is not.
     King: 100% Korrect. The entire number is correct.


At the end of the round, players will state whether their digits were true, false, or both. Points are tallied and play passes to the left.

POINTS
2 points - A correct judgement.
1 point - For each player that you fooled.

JUMPING TO CONCLUSIONS
After a player has chosen their claim, but before the claim is revealed, you can say "Jump to Conclusions!" out loud and point to a player that you think you know their exact answer.

You will say the answer outloud and they will give a yes or no on whether it is 100% correct. If it is, you will gain 5 points. If you are wrong, you gain no points for the entire round and they will gain 1 point for fooling you.

END OF GAME
The game ends when any player reaches 15 points.

Name: ELITE: Epic Strategic Board Game
Description:
Elite is a tabletop strategy game for 2-4 players. Themes include global expansion, resource production, political tactics, economy management, military action, controlling the fate of your dice, planning and timing, completing achievements, and more.

“Players will produce resources, move Elite and armies, assemble new civilians, and spend resources to perform actions. At the end of three Acts, the player with the most Victory Points wins!” - per the designer.

Name: Za kralja i otadžbinu: Đeneral Draža
Description:
Za kralja i otadÅ¾binu: Äeneral DraÅ¾a ("For King and Country: General Mihailovich") is set in WWII Yugoslavia occupied by the Axis and their satellites, while the resistance is divided.

The basic game is for 2 players, one player acting as the leader of the Yugoslav (Royal) Army (Mihailovich), while the other leads the Communist Partisans (Tito). The advanced game is for 1-2 players - the player leading Mihailovich can play solo.

The main goal of both guerrillas is to fight the Axis and the opposing guerrillas, retain the support of the people and Allies, and control Yugoslavia after the war.

If you are Mihailovich in the advanced game, your additional (extremely difficult) goal is also to minimize Serb civilian casualties.

Name: Ekofiskspillet
Description:
With a board formed as the Ekofisk platforms in the North Sea, the objective of Ekofiskspillet ("The Ekofisk Game") is to get to the other side of the platforms by rolling dice and answer trivia questions from question cards along the way.

The board has color codes that tell you what type of questions to answer, much like Trivial Pursuit and other trivia types of games. To make the game family-friendly, one category is marked "C" for "children".

The questions are mostly pop-cultural, with some relating to the oil industry.

For each right answer, you get one point that is written down on the scoreboard. The winner is the player with the most points when the first person has reached the other end of the platforms.

The game is both in English and Norwegian.

Name: Slumpen
Description:
Slumpen (Coincidence) is the main character in a Swedish TV program for children from the 80s.

The game is simple and very similar to the game Snail's Pace Race. In your turn, you roll the color dice and move the figure whose color corresponds to the roll one step. If you roll and the side with all the colors comes up, you can move any game piece to the nearest color square with the same color as the game piece. Whoever first manages to move one of the game piece to the finish line wins.

Name: Oljespill: 48 spørsmål om olje
Description:
Trivia card game.

Answer questions about the oil industry. To win the game you carefully select the right answers from the illustrated cards to get a series of 6 cards complete and win the game.

Name: Inte för en miljon
Description:
Guess right about how much money the other players want to do stunts of varying degrees of scaryness. You are the winner if you are the one who can best predict what your friends are willing to do!

The active player takes a stunt card and reads aloud "Which is the smallest amount of money I would ..." and then the text on the card. Then the active player chooses one of his player cards, which has the values for free, for a thousand kronor, for ten thousand kronor, for a hundred thousand kronor, for a million kronor or not for a million! Other players should now try to figure out the active player's choice. Everyone who matches the active player's choice will receive a 100,000 note. Then it goes on to the next player who reads a stunt card. The first player to collect 1,000,000 wins.

An example of a question might be "... for a month tell every single person I meet that I'm not from this world?"

Name: Dune: Imperium – Jessica of Arrakis Promo Card
Description:
The "Jessica of Arrakis" promo card offered by DireWolf to pre-order customers of Dune Imperium (2020).

Is included in Dune Imperium Promo Pack 1

Agent ability: If you have another Bene Gesserit card in play: draw two cards.

Reveal ability: Gain one persuasion and two battle points.

This card is shuffled into the main draw deck at startup.

Name: Blacks & Whites: 50th Anniversary Edition
Description:
America’s realest real estate game is back!  It’s Blacks & Whites: 50th Anniversary Edition.

Fifty years ago, Prof. Robert Sommer and Judy Tart created a socially-conscious version of Monopoly, highlighting the racial inequity of the housing market and capitalism in America. Inspired by the original, the 50th Anniversary Edition features a new foreward by Prof. Sommer, modern original artwork, entertaining gameplay, and renewed lessons in the economics of prejudice.

The objective is simple: control the board by owning the most property – and hopefully learn something about empathy and cooperation along the way. Play as a Black player: you may feel disenfranchised, but you also get access to Bonus Cards that White players can only dream about!  Or play as White, and this game should be as easy as getting a loan or being seen as human by the police!

—description from the designer

Name: Bilda regering
Description:
Bilda regering ("Forming a government") is a game that wants to show how the work is done in the government and parliament in a country where the people can have their say in free elections. Wants to provide a basic understanding of how democracy works.

Each player represents each of the parties that existed in the Swedish parliament during the seventies. In turn, you roll a dice and walk so many steps along the playing field. After that, you do what is written on the box you have landed on. It may be, for example, that you may place a proposal in one of the Riksdag's committees and mark the relevant sectors of society with a marker, or move the proposals from the committees to the Riksdag's chamber pending a vote that occurs when someone lands on a box marked with a vote.

As soon as there are markers in all sectors of society on the opposition part of the playing field, a government can be formed. The party that has the most markers in the sectors of society is given the task of trying to form a majority government or minority government together with another party.

Every three years there is an election to the Riksdag (represented by the fastest player having reached the start after three laps). Which may lead to the formation of a new government depending on the conditions of the markers in the sectors of society.

Before the game, the player decides how the winner will be chosen. It can, for example, be the party that succeeds in pushing through the most proposals in the Riksdag, the party that after a certain number of rounds has the most points or the party that has managed to stay in government for the longest time.

Name: Dungeons & Detentions
Description:
Overview
Take on the role of new students at the College of Crawlwell and prepare for an enchanted education full of excitement. Students will face typical school challenges such as rivalries, exams and homework, but add in a magical school full of animated objects, traps, and the lure of the many secrets waiting to be discovered. To graduate they will need to keep their head on straight or at least keep it on all together.

Objective:
The objective of the game is to improve your skills, collect resources, and prepare for the final challenge at the end of the game.

Winning Condition:
The player that scores the most points in the final challenge wins.

How the game works:
The game board features a map with many locations. A deck of encounter cards is shuffled and 9 cards are revealed. Players will spend their turn moving around the board to either collect or resolve these encounters, perform special location actions, or attempt to sabotage the other players.

At the start of the game, each player chooses a Major which is a deck of cards the players will use to improve their character throughout the game as players earn experience for resolving encounters.

The game is divided into 15 rounds which involve each player taking a turn. At the end of round 15, players will attempt to defeat a series of Dungeon challenges representing the final exam. Players are scored on how well they perform and the player with the highest score wins.

Name: Patch: The Card Game – Volume One
Description:
Patch: The Card Game is a tool to let players explore their modular synthesis skills in a fun way.

The game can be played solo or as a multiplayer game.

Separate and shuffle the Abstraction cards into their own pile.  Shuffle the Progression a Abstraction cards into another pile. Draw at least one Abstraction card and start patching, following the rule set by that card. The Abstraction card should stay in play for reference.

At some interval (eg. every 5min), draw a card from the Progression/Disruption pile and do the actions described on the card before placing it in a discard pile.  Repeat this as many times as you like until you feel the patch is finished.  If you run out of Progression/Disruptions cards, shuffle the discard pile as your new draw pile.

Patch Battle Royale, or “PBR” for short, is like the multiplayer version of the Basic Game.  2-4 participants is recommended with a single Patch TCG deck.  Multiple decks can be combined for more than 4 players, or if desired for 3 or 4 players to have more cards in their hand.

Start with the Basic Game setup and draw one Abstraction card which will be shared for all players.

Each player then gets dealt 5 cards from the Progression/Disruption pile (4 cards if there are 4 players).
Everyone starts patching.  At some interval, (eg. every 5min), each participant gets to play a single card from their hand.  They can play this card on themselves, in which case they do the action.  Or, they can play it against another player, in which case that player has to do the action.

The battle concludes 5 minutes after the last cards are played. Patches are auditioned/performed/etc and compared.  “Coolest” patch wins.

Name: Misfit Card Game
Description: The Concept - of the game is to play a card value equal to or higher (or according to the rule) than the previous card. If you can't play, you pick up the discard pile. When you run out of cards, you are considered "out". Last person out is the Misfit. The game is based off of a traditional card game call "Sh!thead", among other names. To make it simple, we've created a 1-10 number system for the hierarchy of cards, as well as a few "Power Cards" that can be played on anything. To give Misfit a story and personality, we've chosen a "Warriors" theme for the first available edition. The beauty of Misfit Card Game is we will make many different editions tailored for any person's interests!
Families: Series: Travel Games for Smart Kids (Goldmerk)
Versions & Editions: Travel Versions of Non-Travel Games

Name: Blade Rondo: Frost Veil
Description:
Blade Rondo: Frost Veil is a stand-alone expansion for Blade Rondo. It can be played on its own, using the same rules as the original game, or can be combined with the base game as an expansion.

Rules and cards for playing solo are also included, including some new Solo-play mechanics unique to this expansion.

Blade Rondo is a minimalist, non-collectable card game for two players where each player selects just seven cards per match.

This expansion adds a mechanic for Freezing cards, allowing their effect to be delayed to subsequent turns to add additional strategic depth.

Name: Blade Rondo: Lost Dream
Description:
Blade Rondo: Lost Dream is a stand-alone expansion for Blade Rondo. It can be played on its own, using the same rules as the original game, or can be combined with the base game as an expansion.

Rules and cards for playing solo are also included, including some new Solo-play mechanics unique to this expansion.

Blade Rondo is a minimalist, non-collectable card game for two players where each player selects just seven cards per match.

This expansion does not add any major new card mechanics, instead focusing heavily on offensive abilities.

Name: Victory at Sea: Tribal-class destroyers
Description:
Often called the Afridi-class, this destroyer began the tradition of gunnery over torpedoes. 
However, the class had a frightening lack of anti-aircraft defences, especially against dive-bombers.

The Tribal destroyers were the Royal Navy’s most advanced escorts of the time and saw action in nearly every theatre.

—description from the publisher

Name: 7 Sectors
Description:
A board game for 2 to 6 players where you are one of a crew of astronauts who must collect the Intergalactic Space Biscuit and escape from the Intergalactic Space Pickles to win. Along the way, you must collect colored keys to open colored doors and avoid the Pickles who will try to interfere with your progress. 
The game is a race to the finish that utilizes both dice and a spinner. Collect character cards to purchase the colored keys, teleport around your current Sector, and make your way deeper into the center of the ship to gain the ultimate McGuffin: the Intergalactic Space Biscuit!
Want a longer game? Make your way back out of the ship and to the escape pod to freedom!
Feeling competitive? Bonus spins give you an advantage over other players by taking away their hard-earned cards and keys or even swapping the door colors to foil their strategy!

—description from the designer

Name: Conflicto
Description:
The Game has a board of a part of Europe where the main battles of WWII occurred. There are 12 cities and 6 bridges strategically placed.

This is a game for 2-4 players. Each player has an army of 5 Main Battle Tanks (20 points each), 5 Artillery Pieces (15 points each) and 5 Troops Transport Trucks (10 points each). The units must be placed in their start point accordingly to their color.

In each turn, a player rolls a dice and then can advance their units accordingly. When two or more enemy units reach the same place, a battle can emerge. When the attacker have the same points than the defender, the defender's units return to their starting point, when the attacker have more points, then the defender's units are removed from the board. A player can't attack with less points than the enemy.

There are 4 ways to win in this game:

a) Total anihilation of the enemy.
b) Cities occupattion
c) Invading the enemy's starting point
d) Bridges occupation

Name: Victory at Sea: HMS Dido
Description:
The first WWII mission of Dido was the escort the carrier, Furious to West Africa in November 1940, before spending four months on convoy escort duty in the Atlantic. She then joined operations in the Mediterranean in 1941, assisting in the evacuation of British forces from Crete in May. Badly damaged in these efforts she spent the latter half of that year in the Brooklyn shipyard of New York.

She would return to service in the East Mediterranean, being a key component with only four British ships covering the area. She later served in the Western Mediterranean and supported the Normandy landings in 1944. Her final mission of WWII was to travel to Copenhagen to accept the surrender of the Kriegsmarine. Along the way, she fired the final naval shot of the war in Europe.

—description from the publisher

Name: Victory at Sea: HMS Belfast
Description:
Launched on St Patricks Day 1938, HMS Belfast was one of ten Town-class vessels and the first vessel of the Royal Navy to be named for a Northern Ireland town. She initially operated as part of the British Naval blockade against Germany in 1939. In November of that year, she struck a German mine and spent the next two years undergoing extensive repairs. In November 1942 she returned to action with greater firepower, armour and radar capability.

She escorted Arctic convoys to the Soviet Union in 1943, and later that year was in the Battle of the North Cape, contributing to the destruction of German battleship Scharnhorst. She subsequently assisted in the Normandy landings as part of Operation Overlord and ended the war as part of the British Pacific Fleet. She would go on to see service in the Korean War.

She is now moored as a museum ship on the River Thames in London, operated by the Imperial War Museum.

—description from the publisher

Name: Victory at Sea: HMS Neptune
Description:
Neptune operated during her World War II service with a crew predominantly composed from the New Zealand Division of the Royal Navy, but also a large proportion of South African personnel. In late 1939 she was in pursuit of the German pocket battleship, Admiral Graf Spee. In the aftermath of the Battle of the River Plate she was sent to Uruguay, however, Graf Spee was scuttled before she could arrive.

She participated in the battle of Calabria in July 1940 against the Italian fleet, suffering damage and losing her floatplane in the process, but inflicting heavy damage to the heavy cruiser Bolzano. Subsequently she participated in operations to disrupt convoys attempting to reach Libya with supplies bound for the efforts of Rommel’s Afrika Korps. She met her end on 18 December 1941, in which Force K wandered into an Italian minefield. A total of four mines were struck, leaving only one survivor, Norman Walton, who spent 15 months as a prisoner of war in Italy.

—description from the publisher

Name: Victory at Sea: HMS Duke of York
Description:
Laid down in 1937 and commissioned in 1941, HMS Duke of York was a King George V-class of battleship. She had the distinction of transporting Winston Churchill across the Atlantic to meet Franklin D. Roosevelt in the Winter of 1941. Churchill wrote of his experience, “Being in a ship in weather such as this is like being in a prison, with the extra chance of being drowned”. Between March and September of the next year she was involved mainly in convoy escort duties, but in October was dispatched to Gibraltar to become the flagship of Task Force H.

She saw little action during this period, her main role being protection of the task force’s aircraft carriers, but nevertheless assisted the Allied invasion of North Africa. She subsequently participated in operations to divert Axis attentions away from Sicily in Operation Husky, and Operation Leander in an attempt to disrupt German merchant shipping of the coast of Norway.

On December 26th 1943 HMS Duke of York encountered the German battleship Scharnhorst. Exchanging fire, HMS Duke of York suffered some hits with little effect, but for her part landed several hits upon Scharnhorst, silencing a turret and hitting a boiler room. This forced Scharnhorst on the defensive, and she was sunk by torpedoes as well as further heavy fire from Duke of York.

—description from the publisher
